attributes.title: CAT-MH Adult Probation
attributes.description: System-wide Adaptive Mental Health Measurement and Risk Reduction for Probationers in Cook County, Illinois

q1.value: System-wide Adaptive Mental Health Measurement and Risk Reduction for Probationers in Cook County, Illinois

q3.value: Over a half million people with serious mental illnesses (SMI) are on probation in the United States. Probationers with SMI are more likely to experience probation violations, terminate from probation unsuccessfully, and re-offend post-probation compared to probationers without SMI.  Early and efficient identification of SMI can help probation systems better respond to probationers’ mental health and criminogenic needs. This study entails the secondary analysis of data collected by the Cook County Adult Probation Department (APD) as part of two new initiatives. In the first of these initiatives, APD, in collaboration with Cook County Health (CCH), is implementing the evidence-based Computer Adaptive Testing-Mental Health (CAT-MH) screening tool throughout the APD to more efficiently identify mental health and substance use disorder treatment needs among probationers. In the second initiative, APD recently implemented the use of the Ohio Risk Assessment System (ORAS) to more efficiently identify criminogenic risk factors among probationers. The research team will analyze de-identified CAT-MH data in conjunction with criminogenic risk assessment scores already being collected by APD’s recent implementation of the ORAS risk assessment tool. When examined together, the research team will be able to better understand how mental illness and criminogenic risk affect probation and recidivism outcomes among the probationer population.

q4.value:
This research study will explore the following research questions:

1a. Can a longitudinal mental health screening system be implemented for probationers in Cook County, Illinois that is nationally scalable?
1b. What is the prevalence of mental illness and substance use disorders among the population of probationers in Cook County, Illinois?
2a. How does mental health symptomology interact with assessed criminogenic risk to affect probation compliance, violations, and revocation over time? How do these factors predict recidivism at one year post-probation?
2b. What subgroups of probationers with mental illness and criminal risk factors are more (and less) likely to complete various specialized and standard probation programs?
2c. How do drug use, treatment engagement, and employment mediate the relationship between serious mental illness, criminogenic risk, and recidivism?

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Implementation Study/Secondary Data Analysis

q9.value: This is not a randomized study.

q10.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

q11.value: Some study data have been collected to date, but all study data are not yet available.

question.value: There are no inclusion criteria or exclusion criteria for this study. As part of a department-wide initiative, the APD in conjunction with the local health department, has decided to implement the CAT-MH for use with all new probationers.

q13.value: Recent estimates indicate that the APD receives 11,000 new cases each year. This equates to up to 33,000 probationers who will complete the CAT-MH over the three-year study period.

question.value: Total and CAT-MH sub-domain scores will be analyzed in conjunction with ORAS scores to assess the ability of the CAT-MH to predict primary criminogenic outcomes such as program completion and recidivism, the number and timing of recidivism events, and the seriousness of these events.

The general statistical approach to the analysis of these data is based on linear and non-linear generalized mixed-effects regression models. CAT-MH and ORAS scores at baseline and longitudinal changes in these measures and their sub-domain scores will be used to assess both distal outcomes (e.g. program completion) as well as longitudinal outcomes such as future arrests. Binary outcomes such as program completion or an arrest are examples of mixed-effects logistic regression.  Adding severity of the offense (e.g. felony vs. misdemeanor, charge type) or number of arrests with and without conviction will be analyzed using mixed-effects ordinal regression models with and without proportional odds assumptions.  Time to the first arrest will be analyzed using a discrete-time survival model.  Relaxing the proportional hazards assumption by including a CAT-MH by time interaction will allow us to determine differences in the association between SMI and someone who reoffends within a week versus someone who reoffends after a year.  Counts of events (e.g. arrests within discrete time intervals or the entire longitudinal assessment period) will be analyzed using mixed-effects Poisson regression models, with and without zero inflation.

attributes.title: COVID-19
attributes.description: This study will examine individual self-identity constructs (individualism, collectivism), institutional trust, personal belief in one’s ability to affect their own health (self-efficacy, locus of control), personal willingness to make small personal sacrifices for the safety of others in society (shelter in place, social distancing), and whether narcissism and empathy play a role

q2.value:
Health LOC & Self-Efficacy will positively predict intent to comply.
Political trust, empathy, and collectivism will positively predict intent to comply.
Narcissism will negatively predict intent to comply. 
Collectivism will positively and Narcissism will negatively predict intent to comply over and above Health LOC and Self-Efficacy.

attributes.title: Do Explicit Review Strategies Improve Code Review Performance?
attributes.description:
Context: Code review is a fundamental, yet expensive part of software engineering. Therefore, research on understanding code review and its efficiency and performance is paramount.
Objective: We aim to test the effect of a guidance approach on review effectiveness and efficiency. This effect is expected to work by lowering the cognitive load of the task; thus, we analyze the mediation relationship as well.
Method: To investigate this effect, we employ an experimental design where professional developers have to perform three code reviews. We use three conditions: no guidance, a checklist, and a checklist-based review strategy. Furthermore, we measure the reviewers’ cognitive load.
Limitations: The main limitations of this study concern the specific cohort of participants, the mono-operation bias for the guidance conditions, and the generalizability to other changes and defects.

q1.value: Pavlína Wurzel Gonçalves, Enrico Fregnan, Tobias Baum, Kurt Schneider, Alberto Bacchelli

q2.value: I confirm this study has been granted in-principle acceptance.

attributes.title: The Interaction Between Prosodic and Statistical Cues in French Adults Lexical Segmentation.
attributes.description: Pre-registration of a study investigating how French adults integrate Prosodic and Statistical segmentation cues when performing lexical segmentation of unfamiliar speech.

q1.value: Lexical Segmentation of Unfamiliar Speech in French Adults: The Interaction between Prosodic and Statistical Cues.

q2.value: Alexandre Duroyal, Anne Vilain, Mathilde Fort, Gérard Bailly, Marion Dohen

q3.value:
To segment unfamiliar words from fluent speech, listeners must rely on a combination of different cues. In this study, we investigate the role of two cues: statistical ones and prosodic ones, and how they interact in French adults.

In the learning phase of the study, participants will hear an artificial language made of four trisyllabic words. These four words will be repeated in a random order (with the same word never appearing twice in a row), without pauses between them, for 3 to 4 minutes. An excerpt of the speech stream would be: /gu-do-la-lo-ga-bi-gu-do-la-ba-ti-pu/[…], with gu-do-la being a word.
Only two cues will be available to perform lexical segmentation (i.e. the action of perceiving a group of syllables as one complete word): statistical and prosodic information. Statistical information (that is, how often two syllables follow one another) will always be present. Prosodic information will vary between participants: no prosody (flat), prosodic cues consistent with statistical cues (consistent), and prosodic cues inconsistent with statistical cues (inconsistent). 
While hearing the language, participants will also watch a quick succession of simple images. This will allow us to compare these conditions to a future experiment, where participants will listen to the same languages, but will have to devote their attention to the stream in an attentional one-back task (i.e. they will have to press a button every time they detect the same picture appearing twice in a row).

In the test phase of the experiment, participants will hear 16 different sequences made up of two words they heard in the learning phase. For each sequence, they will have to choose which of the two words correspond to a word of the language they just heard. This choice reflects which words the participants segmented during the learning phase.
For every sequence, one of the words will be a statistical word (e.g. /gu-do-la/ in the sequence /gu-do-la-lo-ga-bi-gu-do-la-ba-ti-pu/[…]). Segmentation of statistical word should have been facilitated by statistical cues.  The other word will be a part-word (e.g. /la-lo-ga/ in the sequence /gu-do-la-lo-ga-bi-gu-do-la-ba-ti-pu/[…]). Segmentation of a part-word should have been impeded by statistical cues. Crucially, when prosodic cues are consistent with statistical cues, prosodic cues should also have facilitated statistical word segmentation, and impeded part-word segmentation. When prosodic cues are inconsistent with statistical cues, however, they should have facilitated part-word segmentation, and impeded statistical-word segmentation.
There will also be four catch trials in the test phase, to ensure participants correctly followed instructions during the learning and test phases.

q4.value:
Participants listening to the language with no prosodic cues (flat condition) should pick statistical words more than by chance.

Participants listening to the language with prosodic cues consistent with statistical cues (consistent condition) should pick statistical words more than in the no prosodic cue condition, and more than by chance.

Participants listening to the language with prosodic cues inconsistent with statistical cues (inconsistent condition), will pick statistical words less than in the no prosodic cue condition. We do not predict if they will chose statistical words more than, less than, or as the same level as chance in this condition.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: Between participants design with 1 factor (Prosody) and 3 levels (Flat, Consistent, Inconsistent).

q9.value:
Each participant will randomly be assigned to one of the three experimental conditions, using the same website where the questionnaire is hosted, Qualtrics.

For each condition, there will be four speech streams, identical in every point except for the order of the words. This will be randomized in the same manner.

q10.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

q11.value: At the time of the pre-registration, the data has been fully collected. The data is online, and has not been downloaded nor accessed by anyone.

question.value:
Participants were mainly psychology students, and were recruited through Social Media. Other non-student participants might have completed the questionnaire, and would have been recruited through word-of-mouth.

Participants had to report being native speakers of French in order to complete the questionnaire.

q13.value: We will have at least 20 participant per condition. The exact number of participants depends on the number of people who completed the questionnaire. Number of participants in each condition may not be exactly balanced, because of our Data exclusion criteria.

q14.value: 20 participant per condition is an arbitrary constraint, widely seen as a minimum number to run analyses.

q15.value: Data collection started on  23/03/2020, and stopped on 27/03/2020. In the unlikely event that we have less than 20 participants in one or more conditions, we will reopen the questionnaire until this condition has been fulfilled.

question.value: We manipulated the type of prosodic information. The three levels of this categorical variable are: No prosody (flat), F0 rise and duration increase on the third syllable of each statistical word (consistent), and F0 rise and duration increase on the second syllable of each statistical word (inconsistent).

One outcome measure will be collected : What kind of word was selected (A statistical word or a part-word). Participant will make the selections by clicking one of two options for each pair.

Two other measures will be  collected: age of participant, and accuracy of their answers to the catch trials.

The data will be analyzed using a mixed model logistic regression. There will be five tests. Accuracy in each of the three conditions (flat, consistent, and inconsistent) will be tested against chance. Two other models will test for a significative difference in accuracy between conditions, one for flat against consistent, and one for flat against inconsistent.

For each model, there will be a random effect of test pair, and a random effect of participant (nested in condition).

Models will be fitted using the Lme4 package. Significance will be assessed using the glht package.

q21.value: We will use the standard p<.05 criteria. One of these test (flat against chance), will be two-tailed. The four other tests will be one-tailed, consistently with our hypotheses. In order to minimize or type II error rate, there will not be corrections for multiple comparisons.

q22.value: We will exclude participants who have not answered correctly all four catch-trials. We will also exclude participants under the age of 17, and over the age of 60.

q23.value: Participants with missing answers will not be included in the statistical analyses.

attributes.title: Smart and funny, but weird: Effects of originality in online dating profile texts on impressions about the profile owner’s personality and attractiveness
attributes.description:
The first goal of this study is to determine how perceived profile text originality affects perceptions of attractiveness and dating intention. More specifically, this study investigates whether different positive and negative personality perceptions, that is, perceived intelligence, sense of humor, and oddness, mediate the relationship between perceived profile text originality and perceived attractiveness and dating intention. To investigate this, a large sample of actual dating site users were presented with real dating profile texts. Participants assessed the profiles’ originality, the profile owners’ perceived attractiveness and their intention to date the profile owner, and rated the profile owners on the mediation variables perceived intelligence, sense of humor, and oddness.

The second goal of this study is to examine in a more exploratory way what characteristics in dating profile texts enhance perceptions of text originality. To do so, all profile texts are manually coded on different meaning and form characteristics that could be indicators of profile text originality. Participants’ scores given to perceived profile text originality scores are then used to indicate what online daters perceive as original meaning and form characteristics, and whether different characteristics of profile text originality affect impression formation differently.

q1.value: Smart and funny, but weird: Effects of originality in online dating profile texts on impressions formed about the profile owner’s personality and attractiveness

q2.value: Tess van der Zanden, Maria Mos, Alexander Schouten, Emiel Krahmer

q3.value:
The broad research questions are:
-	Does originality in profile texts affect impressions that are formed about the profile owners’ attractiveness and what processes underlie this relationship? 

-	What meaning and form characteristics are often found in online dating profile texts that score high on perceived profile text originality?

q4.value:
In this study, we have three directional hypotheses:

H1. Perceived profile text originality increases perceptions of profile owners’ intelligence which, in turn, positively affect perceptions of profile owner’s attractiveness and dating intention.

H2. Perceived profile text originality increases perceptions of profile owners’ sense of humor which, in turn, positively affect perceptions of profile owner’s attractiveness and dating intention.

H3. Perceived profile text originality increases perceptions of profile owners’ oddness which, in turn, negatively affect perceptions of profile owners’ attractiveness and dating intention.

For the second research question regarding the form and meaning characteristics that are common in texts that score high on perceived originality, we do not have any specific hypotheses yet.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

q7.value: Both participants and the researchers will not know to what conditions a participant is assigned.

question.value: In this experiment, each participant sees five different dating profiles which are selected from a larger set of 308 profiles, consisting of a profile text and a blurred profile picture. For each profile, participants are asked to indicate on a scale from 1 to 7 perceptions of profile text originality, profile owner’s intelligence, sense of humor, oddness, physical attractiveness, social attractiveness, romantic attractiveness, and dating intention.

q9.value: A participant will be randomly presented with five profiles matching their indicated sexual preference (randomly assigned but all equally presented).

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
This study concerns an online task. We use Qualtrics to set up the experiment. Our participants will be members of online dating sites who are 18 years and older. For this study, we will collaborate with dating sites, who will help us with participant recruitment. 

The aim is to start the data collection April 2020. The experiment will last about 10 minutes and participation is on a voluntary basis. Participants will not be rewarded for their participation. 

For each participant, the task consists of three phases (Information letter, consent, and demographic questions; Task; Debriefing). First, participants will be welcomed and informed about the procedure of the experiment, and accordingly will answer some demographic questions. Then, participants will be presented with five dating profiles that are composed by the authors. Participants are asked to look at and read the profiles. After each profile text that is read, participants rate on a scale from 1 to 7 how much they agree with 11 statements. One statement concerns the text’s perceived originality, and ten statements regarding perceived attractiveness (physical, social, romantic attractiveness, dating intention) and personality traits of the profile owner (perceived intelligence, sense of humor, oddness). Then, participants will be thanked, debriefed and allowed to leave comments and suggestions.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 600 participants.

q14.value:
To determine the minimum sample size to test our hypotheses, we conducted power calculations by using an (Monte Carlo) power analysis application for mediation models (Schoemann, Boulton, & Short, 2017). For a mediation analysis with multiple mediators, a sample size of 260 should be sufficient (target power = .8, standardized coefficients a = .2, b = .2 and c’ = .1, correlation between mediators = .5).

However, this study has an important exploratory component as one of our study goals is to get a better view on what profile texts are perceived as original, and what text characteristics are perceived as original. The subjective nature of the concept originality requires us a sufficient sample of profile texts ranging in expected originality, but also a sufficient number of ratings per text. Following previous studies on personality inferences from written texts and photos (e.g., Proyer & Brauer, 2018; Penton-Voak, Pound, Little, & Perrett, 2006; Hatch, Hill & Hayes, 1993; Apers & Derous, 2017; Li & Chignell, 2010), ten ratings per text should be enough to estimate the perceived originality of a profile text. 

A total of 308 texts and ten ratings per text leads to 3080 text judgments. With each participant rating five texts, this sums up to a total of 616 participants.

q15.value: As soon as we met our target sample size of 600 participants and an additional 10%, data collection with be terminated.

question.value:
For this study, we selected 308 profile texts from a sample of 31,163 dating profiles from two Dutch dating sites with profiles written by people with different ages and education levels. Profiles were not included in the sample if they contained less than ten or more than hundred words, were written fully in another language than Dutch, or included only the general introduction generated by the dating site. To be able to investigate the effects of perceived text originality on impression formation, we aimed for a range of texts varying in word use. We therefore used the objective measure TF-IDF as a proxy to initially rank the 31,163 profile texts on word use variation. TF-IDF, short for term frequency-inverse document frequency, is a measure often used in information retrieval and text mining, which calculates how often each word in a text appears compared to the frequency of this word in other texts. For each word in a profile text, a TF-IDF score was calculated, and the average of all these scores together was the TF-IDF score of that text. A text with a high average TF-IDF score includes relatively many words that are not found in other texts (and is more likely to score high on perceived profile text originality), while a text with a low average TF-IDF contains a lot of words that also appear relatively often in other texts (and is thus less likely to be perceived as original).

To come to the final sample, the texts were divided into ten percentiles based on the TF-IDF scores. This happens twice: for texts written by people who indicated themselves as men and for people who self-identified as women. Because of data sparsity in the percentiles with the highest TF-IDF scores, the three bins with the texts with the highest TF-IDF scores were combined, leading to a total of seven bins. From each bin, 22 texts were randomly selected, resulting in a total of 154 male texts and 154 female texts, that is, 308 texts altogether. 

Before each selected profile text was accompanied by a blurred profile picture to construct a dating profile, texts were pseudonymized, which means that identifiable information was swapped with information from other profile texts or replaced by information with the same tenor. Texts that could not be pseudonymized (n = 5) or included references to pictures (n = 2) were replaced by another random text taken from the same bin the text originated from. In addition, incomplete sentences at the end of the profiles were removed.

There will be eight outcome variables in this study. One concerns perceptions about the profile text (one item about perceived text originality), the other seven measure perceptions of the owner of the profile. From those seven measuring profile owner perceptions, four are dependent variables regarding perceived attractiveness and dating intention, and three are mediating variables. As dependent variables, we have three dimensions of interpersonal attraction, each measured by one item on a seven-point Likert scale (1 ‘totally disagree’ and 7 ‘totally agree’):
(1)	Social attraction (McCroskey & McCain, 1974), 
(2)	Physical attraction (McCroskey & McCain, 1974) 
(3)	Romantic attraction (Campbell, 1999)

As a fourth independent variable, we have one measure of dating intention which will be measured by a binary question (yes/no), that is, “I would like to go on a date with this person”.  

The three mediating variables, each measured by two items on a seven-point Likert scale, are: 
(5) Perceived intelligence (Leach, Ellemers, & Barreto, 2007)
(6) Perceived sense of humor (following Brand, Bonatsos, D’Orazio, & DeShong, 2012)
(7) Perceived oddness (following Simms, Yufik, Thomas, & Simms, 2008; Ashton & Lee, 2012)

Each mediating variable is measured by two items. With a Spearman correlation test, we will examine whether the two items are correlated. We will use a threshold of .05 and the 95% confidence intervals should not cross 0. If the correlation is higher than .65, we treat the two statements as one construct. If the two items of one construct are correlated, we take the average score of the two to represent one factor. If not, we will consider them separately. 

In previous studies, the constructs perceived intelligence and sense of humor have often been shown to correlate positively. Therefore, we will do a factor analysis. In this analysis, we will look at the eigenvalue of the items of perceived intelligence and sense of humor. Dependent on the results of the factor analysis, we will determine whether perceived intelligence and sense of humor will be clustered for further analyses.

To analyze the data, we will conduct mediation analysis. The independent variable will be perceived text originality (scored by the participants). The ratings of profile owner’s perceived intelligence, sense of humor, and oddness are the mediating variables. The ratings on the three dimensions of attractiveness are the response variables. As such, the following mediation hypotheses will be tested:
H1: The effect of perceived profile text originality on perceived attractiveness and dating intention is mediated by perceived intelligence. 
H2: The effect of perceived profile text originality on perceived attractiveness and dating intention is mediated by perceived sense of humor. 
H3: The effect of perceived profile text originality on perceived attractiveness and dating intention is mediated by perceived oddness. 

To test the mediation hypotheses, we will look at both the direct and mediating effects. Besides examining the mediating effect, we will also look at the direct effects of the independent variables on the mediating variables and of the mediating variables on the response variable. As such, it could be investigated to what extent the mediator explains the, potentially observed, mediation effect. 

If we carry out other, post-hoc analyses to try and explain the results, then these analyses are exploratory and will be listed as such.

q21.value: For the one two-tailed statical analysis we do, we use an alpha level of .05 as our inferential cutoff. Further, we will look into the confidence intervals (95%) and see whether they exceed 0. We will also report effect sizes.

q23.value:
During the experiment, participants cannot skip any statements and will be able to continue to the next profile when rated all of them. Participants are always allowed to stop without reason. 

From those participants who did not complete the entire experiment, the scores given to the profile(s) they have rated will be included in the dataset.

q24.value:
In addition to hypotheses testing, we will also do some exploratory analyses. If results of these exploratory analyses will be described, they will be described and listed as exploratory. 

To answer our second research question, we will conduct an exploratory analysis to identify those form and meaning characteristics in a profile text that affect perceptions of text originality. To do so, we will manually code the profile texts on a number of form (e.g., metaphor use, song text lyrics) and meaning characteristics (e.g., unusual hobbies or character traits) and correlate these with the originality perception scores, and also with the attractiveness scores. 

In addition, we may manually code the profile texts on the occurrence of language errors and include this as a factor in the model, to see whether language error occurrence affects perception scores. 

We will also look into correlations between TF-IDF scores and the scores on perceived profile text originality. 

To examine whether there is some general consensus on what profile texts are perceived as original, mean scores and standard deviations of each text will be calculated based on the different scores given to that one text.

Furthermore, we may also want to examine the effect of profile text length on perceptions on the variables. To examine the extent to which profile text length affects perceptions, we will also do the statistical analyses again but include profile text length as a covariate. 
We will also add the demographic variables (i.e., gender, age, level of education, Dutch as native language, years on dating site) as factors and will examine whether each of those variables affect scores on the response and mediation variables. 

In addition, we may examine whether the perceived originality of participants’ own texts affects their ratings of perceived text originality and the response and mediation variables.     

We may also look into potential differences on the scores given to the variables by the members of the different dating sites.  

If we carry out other analyses to try and explain the results, then these analyses are exploratory and will be listed as such.

registration_responses.q3:
The broad research questions are:
-	Does originality in profile texts affect impressions that are formed about the profile owners’ attractiveness and what processes underlie this relationship? 

-	What meaning and form characteristics are often found in online dating profile texts that score high on perceived profile text originality?
registration_responses.q4:
In this study, we have three directional hypotheses:

H1. Perceived profile text originality increases perceptions of profile owners’ intelligence which, in turn, positively affect perceptions of profile owner’s attractiveness and dating intention.

H2. Perceived profile text originality increases perceptions of profile owners’ sense of humor which, in turn, positively affect perceptions of profile owner’s attractiveness and dating intention.

H3. Perceived profile text originality increases perceptions of profile owners’ oddness which, in turn, negatively affect perceptions of profile owners’ attractiveness and dating intention.

For the second research question regarding the form and meaning characteristics that are common in texts that score high on perceived originality, we do not have any specific hypotheses yet.

registration_responses.q8.question: In this experiment, each participant sees five different dating profiles which are selected from a larger set of 308 profiles, consisting of a profile text and a blurred profile picture. For each profile, participants are asked to indicate on a scale from 1 to 7 perceptions of profile text originality, profile owner’s intelligence, sense of humor, oddness, physical attractiveness, social attractiveness, romantic attractiveness, and dating intention.
registration_responses.q12.question:
This study concerns an online task. We use Qualtrics to set up the experiment. Our participants will be members of online dating sites who are 18 years and older. For this study, we will collaborate with dating sites, who will help us with participant recruitment. 

The aim is to start the data collection April 2020. The experiment will last about 10 minutes and participation is on a voluntary basis. Participants will not be rewarded for their participation. 

For each participant, the task consists of three phases (Information letter, consent, and demographic questions; Task; Debriefing). First, participants will be welcomed and informed about the procedure of the experiment, and accordingly will answer some demographic questions. Then, participants will be presented with five dating profiles that are composed by the authors. Participants are asked to look at and read the profiles. After each profile text that is read, participants rate on a scale from 1 to 7 how much they agree with 11 statements. One statement concerns the text’s perceived originality, and ten statements regarding perceived attractiveness (physical, social, romantic attractiveness, dating intention) and personality traits of the profile owner (perceived intelligence, sense of humor, oddness). Then, participants will be thanked, debriefed and allowed to leave comments and suggestions.

attributes.title: The Effect of Political Xenophobia on Ethnic Identification

q1.value: The Effect of Political Xenophobia on Ethnic Identification

q8.value: Registration prior to realization of outcomes

q15.value: Qualitative researchers have found that many individuals have multiple ethnic identities that they “put on” based on the situation or context (Leach 1954; Waters 1990). According to these largely ethnographic accounts, they do so on the basis of perceived incentives like access to government programs or disincentives like perceived discrimination or stigma. Nevertheless, since most prior studies are observational, it is not clear whether these external factors are actually causing these changes in ethnic identification or whether they are mere byproducts of ethnicity. A separate literature on immigration studies has found that punitive immigration policies may have extra-legal social consequences. Ethnographers have found that high profile anti- immigrant policies like Arizona’s SB 1070 have led immigrants to become anxious about being in public out of fear of being apprehended (Menjivar). Quantitative researchers have found that subnational anti-immigrant policies may have decreased the size of the immigrant Latino population in some communities that considered these laws (Parrado). Though some scholars have argued that immigrants may have fled these communities out of fear, the involved mechanisms are still not well understood. In this study, we test a novel mechanism. In line with prior constructivist approaches to the study of identity, we propose that ethnic identity is contextual and malleable. On the face of perceived political xenophobia, some individuals may shift their identities away from stigmatized categories. This may drive the reduction in Hispanic immigrants as captured in surveys. This protective behavior would be in line with prior research that shows an upsurge in citizenship acquisition. In other words, Latino immigrants may not be physically fleeing these communities. Instead, by choosing not to identify as Latino or as immigrant, they may be becoming invisible for survey researchers. In summary, in this study we test whether exposure to political xenophobia in the form of anti-immigrant policies leads individuals to shift their ethnic identification. Further, to illuminate the mechanisms that mediate this relationship, we will test whether different political acts have distinct consequences. More specifically, we will prime simple immigration statements by a politician, a symbolic policy, and a non-symbolic policy. Each of these political acts may shape identification patterns through different channels.
