attributes.title: Bouba-Kiki Effect Applies to Meaning as well as Shape
attributes.description:
This experiment explores the idea of sound symbolism (i.e., the phenomenon that different language sounds tend to reflect different meanings). In this case, the idea that different phonemes have different affective associations. Specifically, /^/ (as in "glum") is associated with negative affect whereas /i:/ (as in "gleam") is associated with positive affect. Our recent findings have established that people perceive /^/ words as more emotionally negative than /i:/ words (which we have named the gleam-glum effect). Our goal is to further support this hypothesis  using a paradigm similar to the bouba-kiki paradigm. In our experiment, we present pairs of existing words: one with extremely positive affective valence and the other with extremely negative affective valence. Participants are then given a choice between two monosyllabic non-words, which differ only in their vowel. One having the /^/ vowel and the other having the /i:/ vowel. Participants are asked which word provides the best translation for which non-word. For example, given the meanings (words) "good" and "sick" and the non-words "bleem" and "blum", participants can assign the meaning "good" to either "bleem" or "blum" and by default the meaning "sick" to the other.
In addition, the difference in affective valence for each pair will vary to explore the extent to which the effect is indeed driven by affective valence.

q1.value: Bouba-Kiki Effect Applies to Meaning as well as Shape

q2.value: Christine S.P. Yu, Greg Stone, Michael K. McBeath, Viridiana Benitez

q3.value:
This experiment explores the idea of sound symbolism (i.e., the phenomenon that different language sounds tend to reflect different meanings). In this case, the idea that different phonemes have different affective associations. Specifically, /^/ (as in "glum") is associated with negative affect whereas /i:/ (as in "gleam") is associated with positive affect. Our recent findings have established that people perceive /^/ words as more emotionally negative than /i:/ words (which we have named the gleam-glum effect). Our goal is to further support this hypothesis  using a paradigm similar to the bouba-kiki paradigm. In our experiment, we present pairs of existing words: one with extremely positive affective valence and the other with extremely negative affective valence. Participants are then given a choice between two monosyllabic non-words, which differ only in their vowel. One having the /^/ vowel and the other having the /i:/ vowel. Participants are asked which word provides the best translation for which non-word. For example, given the meanings (words) "good" and "sick" and the non-words "bleem" and "blum", participants can assign the meaning "good" to either "bleem" or "blum" and by default the meaning "sick" to the other.
In addition, the difference in affective valence for each pair will vary to explore the extent to which the effect is indeed driven by affective valence.

q4.value:
We first predict that participants have a significantly higher probability of pairing /i:/ non-words with positive words and /^/ non-words with negative words.

We then predict that the magnitude of this effect will depend on the extremity of the difference in affective valence.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
Each participant will receive 50 experimental trials and 50 filler trials. Each experimental trial consists of two words (one high affective valence and one low affective valence) and two non-words (one /^/ and one /i:/). The filler trials are the same as the experimental trials, except the affective valence is not manipulated and the vowels were /u/ (as in BOOT) and /æ/ (as in BAIT) The non-words were monosyllabic and differed only in the vowel.  
Participants select one of the two pairings of word to non-word. The dependent variable is, for each participant, the proportion of trials with the predicted pairings, with chance being 0.5. 
There will be no within participant variables.

q9.value:
This experiment includes 50 pairs of /^/ and /i:/ non-words and 50 pairs of existing words high in either positive or negative emotional valence (the most positive words are  paired with the most negative words). There will also be 50 pairs of /uː/ and /æ/ non-words as fillers (to prevent participants from figuring out the hypothesis), and 50 pairs of relatively neutral words as fillers.

The order to which trials (whether hypothesis-relevant or not) appears in an experiment is completely randomized for each participant. 

The assignment of experimental word pairs to experimental non-word pairs will be counterbalanced across participants. As the filler words and non-words are not relevant to our hypothesis testing, filler non-word pairs will always be paired up with filler word pairs. We will predetermine the filler non-word pair to which a filler word pair will be presented with.

The position to which a non-word appears on the screen (top versus bottom) will be randomized.

 The position of the words (left versus right) will be counterbalanced across participants.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Arizona State University undergraduate students will be recruited through the psychology department subject pool.  
Participants must be fluent in English and may not have a disability related to any of the following categories: reading, speech, hearing or language.

q13.value: Data from approximately 400 participants will be collected and analyzed in the study. The item sample size will be 50.

q14.value:
1. Sample size regarding participants: Our previous study, which was roughly analogous collected data from 61 participants. Results included effects as large as 1.03.

2. Sample size regarding non-word stimuli: We generated all pairs of hypotheses-relevant non-words that met several methodologically necessary constraints. This resulted in 50 experimental trials.

question.value: There are no manipulations or conditions for this experiment. All participants perform in the same condition and the hypothesis is that performance differs from chance (null).

The only measured variable is the probability that participants pair non-words with words in the way we predicted versus not as we have predicted. In other words, we will measure the likelihood for participants to pair /i:/ non-words with positive words and pair /^/ non-words with negative words.
For each participant, we will measure the proportion of trials with the predicted word/non-word pairings. No further transformations will be applied.

We will conduct a binomial test to see if participants have a significantly higher probability of pairing non-words with words in the way we predicted versus not as we have predicted. In other words, we will test if participants are more likely to pair /i:/ non-words with positive words and pair /^/ non-words with negative words.

We will also conduct a Spearman's rank order correlation to see if the effect size decreases as the difference in the affective ratings of the words decreases. This is intended to test if an observed effect is indeed driven by affective valence.

q20.value:
For our binomial test, we will first code each of participants' pairings as A. congruent or B. incongruent. Congruent stands for a pairing that is consistent with our hypothesis: /i:/ non-words paired with positive words and /^/ non-words paired with negative words. Incongruent thus stands for a pairing that contradicts our prediction: /i:/ non-words paired with negative words and /^/ non-words paired with positive words.

For the Spearman's rank order correlation, we will calculate the ratio of participants who have responded as predicted for each real word pair.

q21.value: Both our analyses will be two-tailed tests with an alpha value of .05.

q22.value: We will exclude data from participants who have completed the online experiment in an amount of time that is 2.5 standard deviations shorter than average.

q23.value: A participant's complete set of data will be discarded if he or she does not provide complete data.

q24.value: We will conduct exploratory analyses to see which non-words and real words demonstrate the strongest effect.

registration_responses.q1: Bouba-Kiki Effect Applies to Meaning as well as Shape
registration_responses.q2: Christine S.P. Yu, Greg Stone, Michael K. McBeath, Viridiana Benitez
registration_responses.q3:
This experiment explores the idea of sound symbolism (i.e., the phenomenon that different language sounds tend to reflect different meanings). In this case, the idea that different phonemes have different affective associations. Specifically, /^/ (as in "glum") is associated with negative affect whereas /i:/ (as in "gleam") is associated with positive affect. Our recent findings have established that people perceive /^/ words as more emotionally negative than /i:/ words (which we have named the gleam-glum effect). Our goal is to further support this hypothesis  using a paradigm similar to the bouba-kiki paradigm. In our experiment, we present pairs of existing words: one with extremely positive affective valence and the other with extremely negative affective valence. Participants are then given a choice between two monosyllabic non-words, which differ only in their vowel. One having the /^/ vowel and the other having the /i:/ vowel. Participants are asked which word provides the best translation for which non-word. For example, given the meanings (words) "good" and "sick" and the non-words "bleem" and "blum", participants can assign the meaning "good" to either "bleem" or "blum" and by default the meaning "sick" to the other.
In addition, the difference in affective valence for each pair will vary to explore the extent to which the effect is indeed driven by affective valence.
registration_responses.q4:
We first predict that participants have a significantly higher probability of pairing /i:/ non-words with positive words and /^/ non-words with negative words.

We then predict that the magnitude of this effect will depend on the extremity of the difference in affective valence.
registration_responses.q5: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.
q6: No blinding is involved in this study.
registration_responses.q9:
This experiment includes 50 pairs of /^/ and /i:/ non-words and 50 pairs of existing words high in either positive or negative emotional valence (the most positive words are  paired with the most negative words). There will also be 50 pairs of /uː/ and /æ/ non-words as fillers (to prevent participants from figuring out the hypothesis), and 50 pairs of relatively neutral words as fillers.

The order to which trials (whether hypothesis-relevant or not) appears in an experiment is completely randomized for each participant. 

The assignment of experimental word pairs to experimental non-word pairs will be counterbalanced across participants. As the filler words and non-words are not relevant to our hypothesis testing, filler non-word pairs will always be paired up with filler word pairs. We will predetermine the filler non-word pair to which a filler word pair will be presented with.

The position to which a non-word appears on the screen (top versus bottom) will be randomized.

 The position of the words (left versus right) will be counterbalanced across participants.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to creation of data
registration_responses.q13: Data from approximately 400 participants will be collected and analyzed in the study. The item sample size will be 50.
registration_responses.q14:
1. Sample size regarding participants: Our previous study, which was roughly analogous collected data from 61 participants. Results included effects as large as 1.03.

2. Sample size regarding non-word stimuli: We generated all pairs of hypotheses-relevant non-words that met several methodologically necessary constraints. This resulted in 50 experimental trials.
registration_responses.q20:
For our binomial test, we will first code each of participants' pairings as A. congruent or B. incongruent. Congruent stands for a pairing that is consistent with our hypothesis: /i:/ non-words paired with positive words and /^/ non-words paired with negative words. Incongruent thus stands for a pairing that contradicts our prediction: /i:/ non-words paired with negative words and /^/ non-words paired with positive words.

For the Spearman's rank order correlation, we will calculate the ratio of participants who have responded as predicted for each real word pair.
registration_responses.q21: Both our analyses will be two-tailed tests with an alpha value of .05.
registration_responses.q22: We will exclude data from participants who have completed the online experiment in an amount of time that is 2.5 standard deviations shorter than average.
registration_responses.q23: A participant's complete set of data will be discarded if he or she does not provide complete data.
registration_responses.q24: We will conduct exploratory analyses to see which non-words and real words demonstrate the strongest effect.
registration_responses.q8.question:
Each participant will receive 50 experimental trials and 50 filler trials. Each experimental trial consists of two words (one high affective valence and one low affective valence) and two non-words (one /^/ and one /i:/). The filler trials are the same as the experimental trials, except the affective valence is not manipulated and the vowels were /u/ (as in BOOT) and /æ/ (as in BAIT) The non-words were monosyllabic and differed only in the vowel.  
Participants select one of the two pairings of word to non-word. The dependent variable is, for each participant, the proportion of trials with the predicted pairings, with chance being 0.5. 
There will be no within participant variables.
registration_responses.q12.question:
Arizona State University undergraduate students will be recruited through the psychology department subject pool.  
Participants must be fluent in English and may not have a disability related to any of the following categories: reading, speech, hearing or language.
registration_responses.q16.question: There are no manipulations or conditions for this experiment. All participants perform in the same condition and the hypothesis is that performance differs from chance (null).
registration_responses.q17.question: The only measured variable is the probability that participants pair non-words with words in the way we predicted versus not as we have predicted. In other words, we will measure the likelihood for participants to pair /i:/ non-words with positive words and pair /^/ non-words with negative words.
registration_responses.q18.question: For each participant, we will measure the proportion of trials with the predicted word/non-word pairings. No further transformations will be applied.
registration_responses.q19.question:
We will conduct a binomial test to see if participants have a significantly higher probability of pairing non-words with words in the way we predicted versus not as we have predicted. In other words, we will test if participants are more likely to pair /i:/ non-words with positive words and pair /^/ non-words with negative words.

We will also conduct a Spearman's rank order correlation to see if the effect size decreases as the difference in the affective ratings of the words decreases. This is intended to test if an observed effect is indeed driven by affective valence.

attributes.title: Effects of linguistic diversity on L1 lexical processing and vocabulary development in kindergartners

q1.value: Effects of linguistic diversity on L1 lexical knowledge and processing in kindergartners: behavioral and neural signatures.

q3.value:
Recent information-theoretic perspectives on language acquisition estimate that the majority of information proficient language users store pertains to lexical semantics [1]. A multilingual’s accumulated lexical knowledge is by definition distributed over more than one language. In the current study, we aim to investigate lexico-semantic knowledge and processing of emerging English speakers and the effects of their exposure to other languages. What is the nature of such influence? Are its effects generalizable across multilinguals with different language combinations?
A common finding in the bilingual and multilingual literature is that individuals knowing more than one language perform poorer than monolinguals on monolingual standardized vocabulary tests [e.g., 2,3]. The main source of discrepancies in individual languages’ vocabulary sizes has been attributed to differences in the proportion of time a multilingual is exposed to them [3–8]. For example, Cattani et al. [3] estimate a 60% L1 exposure threshold above which bilinguals perform like monolinguals in the L1: if – for example – an English-Spanish bilingual child is exposed to English and Spanish at a 70-30% ratio, their English vocabulary scores should fall within the range of a monolingual English child, while their Spanish score would be significantly lower than the Spanish monolingual norm. However, other factors than time might be of importance too. Our goal is to better understand the elements of multilinguals’ environment contributing to multilingual lexical development, with particular attention to the effects of linguistic distance between languages.
Languages’ lexicons overlap cross-linguistically to different degrees. Such overlap can be quantified through e.g., comparisons of word lists and computational tools [cf. 9], providing a formalized index of lexical distance between a pair of languages. Our focus is on whether thus quantified relative overlap (similarities) and differences between multilingual children’s languages contribute to the behavioral and neural signatures of lexical knowledge and processing in their dominant (L1) language. Crucially, we gauge both the amount of exposure to other languages and the lexical overlaps between them in order to isolate the effects of the linguistic diversity of children’s environments. 
Although the effect of linguistic distance seems robust for second language (L2) attainment [10–16], direct evidence for its role in L1 is somewhat contradictory and virtually nonexistent for multilingual (as opposed to bilingual) populations. In a recent study performed in a Dutch-speaking environment [17], L1 (Dutch) receptive vocabulary scores of 6-7-year-olds were related to their L2’s distance to Dutch. Lower scores were reported for children whose L2 overlapped least with Dutch; children exposed to languages with a small distance to Dutch, did not differ in terms of their receptive vocabulary from their monolingual peers. Contrastingly, in a study by Floccia et al., [18] smaller linguistic distance between 2-year-olds’ two languages was shown to be related to greater vocabulary outcomes in their L2 but not L1. Children with an L2 whose word forms were close to L1 (English) had a larger expressive L2 vocabulary, and those learning languages whose morphological or syntactic structure was close to English had larger receptive L2 vocabulary scores. There were no significant effects on children’s L1 (English) scores, a finding interpreted along the lines of children’s English acquisition benefitting from growing up in an English-speaking environment, and not from exposure to other languages. Furthermore, the results of Keuleers and colleagues [19] show that multilingualism can in fact have positive effects on L1 vocabulary development in that multilinguals possibly acquire L1 vocabulary indirectly through L2 which outweighs vocabulary loss through decreased L1 exposure. This effect was especially salient for L2s with a relatively small lexical distance with respect to the L1 (i.e., those sharing a large number of vocabulary items). Note however that the study only reported linguistic distance effects of the “best foreign language”, not accounting for lexical overlaps between multilinguals’ other languages, even though some of the participants reported knowledge of six or more languages.
In terms of L1 lexical processing, it has been shown that multilinguals’ processing system is not selective: given a certain proficiency level, other languages than the L1 can influence the processing of multilinguals’ dominant language, be it in the visual [20,21] or auditory domain [22,23]. On neural level, studies show that L1 processing among bilingual subjects is different from that of monolinguals (see [24] for an overview). Overall higher levels of neural activity in bilinguals have been argued to be tied to increased language processing demands in bilingual compared with monolingual participants, a phenomenon referred to as the brain’s “bilingual signature” [25]. 
Whether and to what degree these effects apply to multilinguals with different language combinations is, to the best of our knowledge, unknown. Studies tackling linguistic distance effects on neural level have concentrated on overlaps and dissociations in neural activity across L1 and L2, and not processing differences as a function of multilinguals’ experience. In short, although some studies have reported processing of languages with varied levels of similarity to converge on the same neuronal populations irrespective of linguistic distance [26], others tied larger linguistic distance to the use of additional neural resources during reading [27], or syntactic processing [28], along with evidence for stronger leftward lateralization for L2 auditory processing that is more similar to L1 [29].
The current study seeks to answer the question of whether typology and relative lexical dis-tance between a multilingual’s languages explain variance in their L1 vocabulary knowledge in addition to language exposure measures accounting for time only [cf. 3–7]. Furthermore, we are interested in the neural mechanisms driving these effects, aiming at establishing the neural signatures of linguistic diversity of the environment in which multilingual children grow up and develop their language skills. 
Treating multilingualism as a spectrum of experiences and not a dichotomous category [cf. 30–32], our approach is to describe multilingual children’s language experiences as closely as possible (see however [e.g., 33,34] for language environment estimates much more extensive than ours). We used a detailed parental questionnaire and in-person interviews and calculated the length of cumulative exposure to any language each child in the sample came into contact with during their lives. We then gathered information pertaining to relative linguistic distances between each child’s languages, based on languages’ lexicons. From these data, we derived three indices representing children’s cumulative language exposure, putatively influencing the L1 (English) vocabulary knowledge and processing in our sample: (1) proportion of CUMULATIVE LENGTH OF EXPOSURE to English, (2) DIVERSITY OF LANGUAGE EXPOSURE, describing the variability of language input irrespective of language combinations but accounting for cumulative length of exposure to all languages, and (3) TYPOLOGICAL DIVERSITY OF LANGUAGE EXPOSURE – an index accounting for the linguistic distance between participants’ languages and relative lengths of exposure at the same time. Using English receptive and expressive vocabulary scores as our outcome variables on one hand, and cortical activation levels during two lexical functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) tasks on the other, we aim to run separate regression models to assess whether our language diversity index accounting for the linguistic distance between participants’ languages will account for variance above and beyond the other two indices. Voxel-wise visualizations of model assessment applied to the fMRI data [35] will be used to specify the spatial scope of these effects.
Our approach is novel is several respects. From a methodological point of view, we leverage computational tools from information technology – Shannon’s [36] entropy, and the study of ecological diversity – Rao’s [37] quadratic entropy index of diversity, thus offering a pioneering, multi-dimensional quantification of language exposure in multilinguals. By modelling language exposure of our sample as is, and not handpicking our groups of interest, we therefore offer an ecologically valid way of describing the multilingual language experience, an approach rarely followed (see e.g. [30,38] for noteworthy exceptions) but highly called for in the multilingual literature [cf. 32,39]. To the best of our knowledge, we are the first to investigate linguistic distance effects in a group of multilingual children, accounting for typological relations between all their languages. Lastly, we offer an insight not only into the behavioral manifestations of multilingual upbringing but also its neural correlates, thus filling an important gap in research on L2-learning-induced neuroplasticity driven by language typology [cf. 40].

q4.value:
I.	We expect to replicate the established correlations between children’s L1 (English) vocabulary knowledge and measures accounting for the relative proportion of time they were exposed to English [cf. 3–6].
II.	More variance in children’s vocabulary knowledge and lexical processing neuroimaging data will be explained by the measure of language exposure that accounts for the linguistic distance between their languages than by measures modeling the time aspect only.
III.	Linguistic distance will moderate the relationship between language exposure and behavioral and neural markers of lexical processing in that exposure to more distant languages will result in (a) lower English vocabulary scores [cf. 17,19], and (b) L1 processing on neural level being characterized by the neural signature [cf. 25] with the activation levels linearly contingent on the degree of linguistic overlap between the languages [cf. 27,28].

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This is a cross-sectional study with within-subject design.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value:
Data are part of a larger, longitudinal study investigating literacy development in multilingual populations. Data for the present study are cross-sectional and have been collected as the first time-point in the larger project.
Any analyses already performed were done for validation purposes during development of our indices only. No analysis pertaining to the present research questions and hypotheses were done.
Neuroimaging data have been preprocessed, following established protocols for fMRI experi-ments (motion correction, spatial smoothing, registration to a common template, see Section ‘Measured variables Neuroimaging data’ for further details), followed by time-series statistical analyses on individual level. Similar to our behavioral measures, no investigation concerning the comparisons of interest for the current study has been performed.

question.value:
All procedures were approved by the University of California San Francisco Institutional Review Board.
Participants were recruited through flyers, community outreach events and social media advertisements. Data collection started in October 2015 and finished in January 2019. Each year a new cohort of kindergartners (5-6-year-olds) participated in the study between October and January of their first year of formal schooling. Behavioral and neuroimaging data were collected on separate occasions, with – on average – 23 days between the two appointments (for participants included in the current analyses).
For each appointment, participants were paid $40 in cash. The behavioral assessments were administered by trained research staff on a one-to-one basis. For language exposure data, we used detailed parental questionnaires and in-person interviews. Information about relative linguistic distances between each child’s languages was gathered through the Automated Similarity Judgment Program (ASJP) Database (http://asjp.clld.org/) [41].
Neuroimaging data were collected using a 3-T Siemens Prisma Fit MRI scanner equipped with a 64-channel head coil. Children were familiarized with the experimental procedures prior to scanning. We used padding to dampen scanner noise and reduce motion, and delivered sound (experimenter instructions, movie during structural scans and auditory stimuli during the fMRI runs) through an MRI compatible sound-system. Participants responses were recorded with a button box. All tasks were created and presented in E-Prime software [42].
Whole-brain functional images were acquired using a gradient-echo echo-planar pulse sequence (TR = 1250ms, TE = 33.40ms, FA = 45º, FOV = 220mm, voxel size = 2.2mm3, 64 contiguous 2.20mm axial slices, 0mm inter-slice gap). High resolution T1-weighted anatomical images were acquired with a matrix size of 256*256; 160 contiguous axial slices; voxel resolution 1 mm, TR =2300ms, TE = 2.98ms, T1 = 900ms; and FA = 9.

q13.value:
A total of 184 children participated in at least one of our behavioral assessments and were invited for the neuroimaging experiment; the available full behavioral dataset (including all dependent and independent variables) comprises of 160 data points. 
157 children took part in the neuroimaging data collection. Two experimental tasks will be analyzed: English auditory word match task and English auditory semantic word match task (see ‘Measured variables’ Section for more details). Due to movement during the fMRI scans, failure to complete all experimental runs or hardware changes, respectively 101 and 98 datasets are available for higher-level analyses in the current study.

q14.value: A priori power analyses for sample size calculation have been conducted with a different, longitudinal design in mind. With the available sample size, for frequentist multiple regression analyses, the available sample size gives us the sensitivity for detecting a medium effect size (ƒ2 = 0.18) at alpha = .05 (Bonferroni corrected) and with .95 power [43].

question.value:
Independent variables

Our predictor variables used in both the behavioral and neuroimaging analyses are a combination of LANGUAGE EXPOSURE data and LEXICAL DISTANCE between languages. A detailed description of the way the basic measurements were combined for the final analyses can be found in the Section ‘Indices’ below. The following pieces of data will be included in the calculation of the indices:
(1)	Language Exposure data were collected using detailed parental questionnaires and in-person interviews. The length of cumulative exposure to any language each child in the sample came into contact with during their lives was calculated following methods de-scribed in [44] and using an adapted (from three to five languages) version of the ‘Amount of language exposure in the past’ section of the Bilingual Language Experience Calculator (BiLEC) form. The following information was used: 
        a.	how many and which languages a child has been exposed to so far at home, (if applicable) at daycare and in any other structured way (e.g., through a baby-sitter or a play group). We include also relatively short language experiences (“1 hour a week for 6 months”), since even limited language exposure have been reported to have a significant impact on individual’s cognitive outcomes [45,46];
        b.	what proportion of time each adult or sibling living in the house spoke English or another language for each one-year period in the child’s life; 
        c.	if the child attended daycare, or other out-of-school activities, how much time did they spend there per week and what was the approximate time ratio of languages used for instruction for each one-year period in the child’s life;
        d.	time spent at school and language use at school quantified based on data available on San Francisco Unified School District (SFUSD)  website (http://www.sfusd.edu/en/enroll-in-sfusd-schools/language-pathways.html) and individual schools’ websites.
(2)	Lexical Distances between each child’s languages were collected through the Automated Similarity Judgment Program (ASJP) Database (http://asjp.clld.org/) [41]. ASJP is a tool aimed at objective, data-driven evaluation of similarity between words with the same mean-ing from different languages, and computational classification of languages based on their lexical similarity. The distance values were collected by comparing lists of words pertaining to a set of 40 concepts specified in [47]. The word lists were transcribed using a system called “ASJPcode” – a transcription into a simplified standard orthography, described in [48]. Words were compared with each other based on their Levenshtein Distance [49], being the minimum number of changes (insertions, deletions or substitutions) necessary to convert one word into another. Levenshtein Distance Normalized Divided (LDND) was used in the present study, given its robustness against chance resemblances [50]. LDND is a result of, first, a correction for differences in word length by dividing the raw Levenshtein distance by the number of symbols of the longer of the two words being compared (resulting in LDN – Levenstein Distance Normalized), followed by dividing the LDN by the average LDN of words not referring to the same concept. The distances were computed using the program ASJP.R by Wichmann (https://github.com/Sokiwi/InteractiveASJP01). All data are freely available from [41] (http://asjp.clld.org/).


Dependent variables 

Behavioral data
Two outcome variables are used in the study: a measure of RECEPTIVE and EXPRESSIVE English vocabulary. 
(1)	Receptive (Standard American) English vocabulary was measured with the Peabody Pic-ture Vocabulary Test (PPVT), 4th Edition, Form A [51]. In this test, the participant is asked to pick one out of four pictures that best described a word stated by the examiner for each question by either pointing at the picture or stating the number assigned to a picture. The test takes approximately 20 minutes to complete. The test has been shown to have good to excellent internal consistency (.89–.97) and test-retest reliability (.87–.93).
(2)	Expressive English vocabulary was measured with the Picture Vocabulary subtest of the Woodcock-Johnson, 4th Edition (WJ-IV-PV), Tests of Oral Language [52,53]. The Picture Vocabulary subtest is an expressive language measure at the single-word level, where the participant is asked to name pictures. It measures oral language development and lexical knowledge. Participants are asked to identify pictured objects. The items become increasingly difficult as the selected pictures appear less frequently in the environment. The basal level is established when 6 of the lowest consecutive items are answered correctly. The test is terminated if the participant misses 6 items in a row. The test takes approximately 8 minutes to complete. Extensive information on the WJ’s internal and external validity evidence can be found in [54]. 
Covariates of no-interest. The following covariates of no-interest will be used in the analyses: participant’s age at the moment of testing, their gender, socioeconomic status (SES), and depending on the relations observed in the data (i.e., existence of associations with both the independent and dependent variables), nonverbal reasoning skills measured by the Kauffman Brief Intelligence Test, 2nd Edition (KBIT-2) [55]. See Section ‘Indices’ below for the description of how the SES index was calculated.

Neuroimaging data
Description of tasks. Two experimental tasks will be analyzed: (1) English Auditory Word-Form Match Task (henceforth Word-Form Match Task) and (2) English Auditory Semantic Word Match Task (henceforth Semantic Match Task). See [56] for a full description of task (1). For clarity, both tasks are also described in detail below. The tasks consisted of consecutive auditory presentation of two English words. Children were asked to indicate (with a button press) whether the words matched in form [task (1)] or were semantically related [task (2)]. Each task was presented in a separate 3.8 min functional run and consisted of 6 blocks separated by 12 s inter-block rest periods. 24 trials were included in each block, half of which were matching in form or were semantically related. Each 6 s trial consisted of Word 1, followed by Word 2 2000 ms later, followed by a 2000 ms question mark (see attached 'in-scanner-tasks-illustration.pdf'). 
Stimuli. 
(1)	Word-Form Match Task: Participants heard two words and were asked to indicate via but-ton press whether the two words were the same or not (e.g., “pants” – “pants” = yes, “hole” – “mop” = no). For each individual trial, stimuli were matched for the number of syllables and phonemes. All words had one or two syllables and were an average of 4.23 phonemes long. 
(2)	Semantic Match Task: Participants heard two words and were asked to indicate via button press whether or not the two words “go together,” or are semantically related (e.g., “sing – dance” = yes, “rabbit – stroller” = no). As defined by the University of South Florida Free Association Norms, semantically related pairs had a mean forward association strength of 0.35, ranging from 0.05 (“notebook – pencil”) to 0.76 (“table – chair”). Non-matching pairs had no association [57]. Although we attempted to match the number of syllables and pho-nemes across the two words in each trial, many strongly associated words varied in length (e.g., “gift – birthday,” or “forest – tree.” Nevertheless, all words had one or two syllables, and were an average of 4.19 phonemes long. There were no significant differences in pho-neme length, age of acquisition, verbal frequency, written frequency or imageability be-tween words semantically associated trials as compared to non-matching trials [58]. 
Pre-processing parameters. Imaging data were processed using FSL software Version 6.0.0 (FMRIB's Software Library, http://www.fmrib.ox.ac.uk/fsl [59]). Pre-processing was carried out using FEAT (FMRI Expert Analysis Tool) Version 6.00. The pre-statistics processing steps included: removal of the first 11 volumes for signal equilibration (173 volumes retained); motion correction using MCFLIRT [60]; non-brain removal using BET [61]; grand-mean intensity normalization of the entire 4D dataset by a single multiplicative factor; spatial smoothing using a Gaussian kernel of 5 mm FWHM; B0 unwarping using BBR (Boundary-Based Registration; https://fsl.fmrib.ox.ac.uk/fsl/fslwiki/FLIRT_BBR; [60,62]), which also performs simultaneous registration to the high resolution T1-image (rigid body, 6 degrees of freedom). After this, T1-images were registered to MNI-152 standard space using 12-parameter affine transformation and non-linear registration with a warp resolution of 10 mm in FNIRT [63,64]. After conducting standard data preprocessing, in order to identify and remove head motion-related artefacts from functional MRI data, ICA-AROMA (Independent Component Analysis-based Automatic Removal of Motion Artifacts; https://github.com/maartenmennes/ICA-AROMA; [65]) was performed, but only on data that passed motion quality control (i.e., data where the absolute mean displacement during the run was less than 5mm). The de-noised data were then high-pass filtered with a cutoff of 36 s (0.036 Hz) and the registration parameters were reapplied. 
Single-level statistical analysis. Time-series statistical analysis was carried out using FILM with local autocorrelation correction [66]. The design matrices for each run for each participant included task blocks as events of interest with signal from white matter and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) as nuisance regressor. 
Dependent variables. Relative levels of BOLD signal during task blocks compared to rest blocks derived from the single-level statistical analyses of each of the experimental runs (Word-Form and Semantic Match Tasks).
Covariates of no-interest. Participants’ demographic variables will be the same as for the behavioral data. In addition, each statistical model at individual level included white matter and CSF signal as nuisance regressors. Group-level analyses will additionally include participant’s handedness (coded as -1,0,1 for left-handed, ambidextrous and right-handed respectively) and an index of their behavioral performance on the task (see Section ‘Indices’ below).

Cumulative Length of Exposure to English. 
The Cumulative Length of Exposure to English was calculated using information gathered with the BiLEC form (see Section ‘Measured variables’ above). Details with regards to exact calculations can be found in the instrument’s manual available at https://www.iris-database.org/iris/app/home/detail?id=york%3A928327&ref=search. As per authors’ instructions some country-specific and participant-specific data were changed in the form, including values for average number of hours at school, number of weeks’ holiday per year. In our analyses, we used the proportion of Cumulative Length of Exposure to English, which was calculated by dividing the total English exposure BiLEC-derived value (in years) by participant’s age at testing.

Diversity of Language Exposure. 
The Diversity of Language Exposure indexed how variable each participant’s language exposure was irrespective of particular language combinations but accounting for cumulative length of exposure to all languages. We computed it using the Shannon’s entropy (H) equation [36]: (see attached)
where, n stands for the total number of languages a participant has been exposed to and pi is the proportion of time (in years) a participant was exposed to that language during their life. We calculated the Diversity of Language Exposure index using the “entropy” R package (https://rdrr.io/cran/entropy/). 

Typological Diversity of Language Exposure. 
The Typological Diversity of Language Exposure index was created using Rao's quadratic entropy equation (QE) [37,67,68]. The summed lexical distances between all language pairs for each child were weighted by the length of exposure to each language as follows:
If the proportion of cumulative length of exposure to i-th language in a child’s repertoire is pi and the dissimilarity between language i and j is dij, then Typological Diversity of Language Exposure has the form: (see attached)
where dij varies from 0 (i.e., the two languages have exactly the same lexicons) to 1 (i.e., where the two languages have completely different lexicons). We calculated the Typological Diversity of Language Exposure index using the “SYNCSA” R package (https://rdrr.io/cran/SYNCSA/).

Socio-economic status (SES). 
Following our previous work [69], SES was indexed as the highest level of education in years attained by each parent. We created one SES metric by averaging education levels of both parents.

Accuracy on the fMRI tasks. 
To account for response bias participants’ responses on the two fMRI tasks were transformed into d’ scores [70], representing the standardized difference between the means of Hit Rate (HR) – proportion of YES trials to which subject responded YES, and False Alarm Rate (FAR) – proportion of NO trials to which subject responded YES:
(see attached)

Hypothesis I: L1 vocabulary knowledge is related to the cumulative length of exposure to English (replication)

L1 vocabulary and length of exposure correlations

We expect to replicate the established correlations between children’s L1 (English) vocabulary knowledge and measures accounting for the relative proportion of time they were exposed to English [cf. 3–6].
Method. Linear models with covariates of no-interest will be used to determine the existence and strength of the effect of cumulative length of exposure to English on L1 knowledge. Two separate analyses will be done, each for one of the two outcome variables: (1) receptive vocabulary scores (indexed by PPVT) and (2) expressive vocabulary scores (indexed by WJ-IV-PV). We will follow model comparison procedure [cf. 71] by (in each case) fitting a baseline model (containing only the covariates of no-interest) and a model additionally containing the Cumulative Length of Exposure variable. See ‘Inference criteria’ Section for further information on significance testing.

Exposure threshold for monolingual-like performance 

In addition, we aim to replicate Cattani et al.’s [3] finding of a 60% exposure to English cut-off point above which bilinguals (multilinguals in our case) should perform on a par with English monolinguals. 
Method. We will follow a procedure similar to [3], i.e., a two-stage cluster analysis consisting of (1) approximation of data grouping via a hierarchical cluster analysis, and (2) its refinement with a k-means cluster analysis. In addition, we will perform curve-fitting analyses, estimating linear, quadratic and cubic relationships between the dependent and independent variables [8], which will be followed by a rolling regression analysis. This last step will be performed in order to provide further evidence for whether the model parameters are constant over the whole range of English cumulative exposure data. We will compute parameter estimates over a rolling window with a fixed sample size through the entire sample. No (or negligible) change in the estimates over the rolling windows will point to the parameters being truly constant over our entire sample. A change in parameters with a certain exposure threshold value will be signified by a change in the estimates.


Hypothesis II: Linguistic distance explains variance above length of exposure 

Here, we hypothesize that more variance in children’s vocabulary knowledge and lexical processing neuroimaging data (i.e., the two fMRI tasks data) will be explained by the measure of language exposure that accounts for the linguistic distance between their languages than by measures modeling the time aspect only.

Behavioral data

Method. Two separate analyses will be done, each for one of the two outcome variables: (1) receptive vocabulary scores (indexed by PPVT) and (2) expressive vocabulary scores (indexed by WJ-IV-PV). We will employ model comparison procedure by fitting three linear models (plus a baseline model) to our two outcome variables. The baseline model will only include the covariates of no-interest. The other three models will additionally include the three indices of language exposure (i.e., Cumulative Length of Exposure to English, Diversity of Language Exposure and Typological Diversity of Language Exposure). See ‘Inference criteria’ Section for further information on significance testing.

Neuroimaging data

A similar logic will be applied to the neuroimaging data, i.e., we will aim at establishing which of our indices of language exposure best predicts group-level BOLD data acquired during the (1) Word-Form Match Task and the (2) Semantic Match Task. We will fit General Linear Models (GLMs) to the group-level data and assess their quality. The models will similarly include covariates of no-interest along with regressors of interest (i.e., the three language exposure indices). We will follow model assessment procedures described in [35,72,73].


Hypothesis III: Linguistic distance moderates the relationship between language exposure and behavioral and neural markers of lexical processing

Behavioral data

Given that being exposed to more than 2 languages in total means that these languages’ lexicons also ‘interact’ with one another, in order to isolate the moderating effect of linguistic distance on the language exposure – vocabulary knowledge relation, we will only test this hypothesis in a sub-sample of participants who reported exposure to English and only one other language, i.e., bilinguals. In terms of directionality of the effect, we expect that exposure to more distant languages results in lower English vocabulary scores [cf. 17,19].
Method. The moderating effect of language distance on the relationship between the length of language exposure and (1) receptive and (2) expressive vocabulary will be tested by looking for significant interactions between the language distance variable and the length of exposure variable using multiple regression analyses. The existence of the moderating effect will be established through model comparison procedure, strength of the effect by inspecting the parameter estimates and visual inspection of slopes of the moderating effect.

Neuroimaging data 

Method. Group-level General Linear Model analyses will be performed. Similarly, we will look for a significant interaction term between the language distance variable and the length of exposure variable, controlling for covariates of no-interest as indicated above.

q20.value: All data will be mean centered for the analyses.

q21.value:
Three types of inference criteria will be employed: frequentist, Bayesian and visual inspection of the data. For frequentist approaches, will use the standard p < .05 criterion for determining if the models suggest that the results are significantly different from those expected if the null hypothesis were correct. Bayes factors will be used and interpreted following [72–77] and will inform our models selection. We will compare models with BIC [78] and the difference between two BICs will be converted into a Bayes factor using the equation below, following [74]: (see attached)

Visual inspection of the relationship observed in the data will be employed for the rolling window regression analysis (Hypothesis I) and to evaluate the moderation effects (Hypothesis III). All voxel-wise visualizations of the BOLD data will be subject to visual interpretation (in conjunction with the use of anatomical atlases available via the visualization software).

q22.value: Data have been excluded at level of preprocessing due to: missing data, movement during fMRI scans (> 5mm), failure to complete all experimental runs, and hardware changes. In addition, we will not analyze data with lower than chance accuracy on the tasks, or data from participants who have not been exposed to English from birth.

q23.value: Only participants who provided complete datasets will be included in the analyses.

registration_responses.q1: Effects of linguistic diversity on L1 lexical knowledge and processing in kindergartners: behavioral and neural signatures.
registration_responses.q3:
Recent information-theoretic perspectives on language acquisition estimate that the majority of information proficient language users store pertains to lexical semantics [1]. A multilingual’s accumulated lexical knowledge is by definition distributed over more than one language. In the current study, we aim to investigate lexico-semantic knowledge and processing of emerging English speakers and the effects of their exposure to other languages. What is the nature of such influence? Are its effects generalizable across multilinguals with different language combinations?
A common finding in the bilingual and multilingual literature is that individuals knowing more than one language perform poorer than monolinguals on monolingual standardized vocabulary tests [e.g., 2,3]. The main source of discrepancies in individual languages’ vocabulary sizes has been attributed to differences in the proportion of time a multilingual is exposed to them [3–8]. For example, Cattani et al. [3] estimate a 60% L1 exposure threshold above which bilinguals perform like monolinguals in the L1: if – for example – an English-Spanish bilingual child is exposed to English and Spanish at a 70-30% ratio, their English vocabulary scores should fall within the range of a monolingual English child, while their Spanish score would be significantly lower than the Spanish monolingual norm. However, other factors than time might be of importance too. Our goal is to better understand the elements of multilinguals’ environment contributing to multilingual lexical development, with particular attention to the effects of linguistic distance between languages.
Languages’ lexicons overlap cross-linguistically to different degrees. Such overlap can be quantified through e.g., comparisons of word lists and computational tools [cf. 9], providing a formalized index of lexical distance between a pair of languages. Our focus is on whether thus quantified relative overlap (similarities) and differences between multilingual children’s languages contribute to the behavioral and neural signatures of lexical knowledge and processing in their dominant (L1) language. Crucially, we gauge both the amount of exposure to other languages and the lexical overlaps between them in order to isolate the effects of the linguistic diversity of children’s environments. 
Although the effect of linguistic distance seems robust for second language (L2) attainment [10–16], direct evidence for its role in L1 is somewhat contradictory and virtually nonexistent for multilingual (as opposed to bilingual) populations. In a recent study performed in a Dutch-speaking environment [17], L1 (Dutch) receptive vocabulary scores of 6-7-year-olds were related to their L2’s distance to Dutch. Lower scores were reported for children whose L2 overlapped least with Dutch; children exposed to languages with a small distance to Dutch, did not differ in terms of their receptive vocabulary from their monolingual peers. Contrastingly, in a study by Floccia et al., [18] smaller linguistic distance between 2-year-olds’ two languages was shown to be related to greater vocabulary outcomes in their L2 but not L1. Children with an L2 whose word forms were close to L1 (English) had a larger expressive L2 vocabulary, and those learning languages whose morphological or syntactic structure was close to English had larger receptive L2 vocabulary scores. There were no significant effects on children’s L1 (English) scores, a finding interpreted along the lines of children’s English acquisition benefitting from growing up in an English-speaking environment, and not from exposure to other languages. Furthermore, the results of Keuleers and colleagues [19] show that multilingualism can in fact have positive effects on L1 vocabulary development in that multilinguals possibly acquire L1 vocabulary indirectly through L2 which outweighs vocabulary loss through decreased L1 exposure. This effect was especially salient for L2s with a relatively small lexical distance with respect to the L1 (i.e., those sharing a large number of vocabulary items). Note however that the study only reported linguistic distance effects of the “best foreign language”, not accounting for lexical overlaps between multilinguals’ other languages, even though some of the participants reported knowledge of six or more languages.
In terms of L1 lexical processing, it has been shown that multilinguals’ processing system is not selective: given a certain proficiency level, other languages than the L1 can influence the processing of multilinguals’ dominant language, be it in the visual [20,21] or auditory domain [22,23]. On neural level, studies show that L1 processing among bilingual subjects is different from that of monolinguals (see [24] for an overview). Overall higher levels of neural activity in bilinguals have been argued to be tied to increased language processing demands in bilingual compared with monolingual participants, a phenomenon referred to as the brain’s “bilingual signature” [25]. 
Whether and to what degree these effects apply to multilinguals with different language combinations is, to the best of our knowledge, unknown. Studies tackling linguistic distance effects on neural level have concentrated on overlaps and dissociations in neural activity across L1 and L2, and not processing differences as a function of multilinguals’ experience. In short, although some studies have reported processing of languages with varied levels of similarity to converge on the same neuronal populations irrespective of linguistic distance [26], others tied larger linguistic distance to the use of additional neural resources during reading [27], or syntactic processing [28], along with evidence for stronger leftward lateralization for L2 auditory processing that is more similar to L1 [29].
The current study seeks to answer the question of whether typology and relative lexical dis-tance between a multilingual’s languages explain variance in their L1 vocabulary knowledge in addition to language exposure measures accounting for time only [cf. 3–7]. Furthermore, we are interested in the neural mechanisms driving these effects, aiming at establishing the neural signatures of linguistic diversity of the environment in which multilingual children grow up and develop their language skills. 
Treating multilingualism as a spectrum of experiences and not a dichotomous category [cf. 30–32], our approach is to describe multilingual children’s language experiences as closely as possible (see however [e.g., 33,34] for language environment estimates much more extensive than ours). We used a detailed parental questionnaire and in-person interviews and calculated the length of cumulative exposure to any language each child in the sample came into contact with during their lives. We then gathered information pertaining to relative linguistic distances between each child’s languages, based on languages’ lexicons. From these data, we derived three indices representing children’s cumulative language exposure, putatively influencing the L1 (English) vocabulary knowledge and processing in our sample: (1) proportion of CUMULATIVE LENGTH OF EXPOSURE to English, (2) DIVERSITY OF LANGUAGE EXPOSURE, describing the variability of language input irrespective of language combinations but accounting for cumulative length of exposure to all languages, and (3) TYPOLOGICAL DIVERSITY OF LANGUAGE EXPOSURE – an index accounting for the linguistic distance between participants’ languages and relative lengths of exposure at the same time. Using English receptive and expressive vocabulary scores as our outcome variables on one hand, and cortical activation levels during two lexical functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) tasks on the other, we aim to run separate regression models to assess whether our language diversity index accounting for the linguistic distance between participants’ languages will account for variance above and beyond the other two indices. Voxel-wise visualizations of model assessment applied to the fMRI data [35] will be used to specify the spatial scope of these effects.
Our approach is novel is several respects. From a methodological point of view, we leverage computational tools from information technology – Shannon’s [36] entropy, and the study of ecological diversity – Rao’s [37] quadratic entropy index of diversity, thus offering a pioneering, multi-dimensional quantification of language exposure in multilinguals. By modelling language exposure of our sample as is, and not handpicking our groups of interest, we therefore offer an ecologically valid way of describing the multilingual language experience, an approach rarely followed (see e.g. [30,38] for noteworthy exceptions) but highly called for in the multilingual literature [cf. 32,39]. To the best of our knowledge, we are the first to investigate linguistic distance effects in a group of multilingual children, accounting for typological relations between all their languages. Lastly, we offer an insight not only into the behavioral manifestations of multilingual upbringing but also its neural correlates, thus filling an important gap in research on L2-learning-induced neuroplasticity driven by language typology [cf. 40].
registration_responses.q4:
I.	We expect to replicate the established correlations between children’s L1 (English) vocabulary knowledge and measures accounting for the relative proportion of time they were exposed to English [cf. 3–6].
II.	More variance in children’s vocabulary knowledge and lexical processing neuroimaging data will be explained by the measure of language exposure that accounts for the linguistic distance between their languages than by measures modeling the time aspect only.
III.	Linguistic distance will moderate the relationship between language exposure and behavioral and neural markers of lexical processing in that exposure to more distant languages will result in (a) lower English vocabulary scores [cf. 17,19], and (b) L1 processing on neural level being characterized by the neural signature [cf. 25] with the activation levels linearly contingent on the degree of linguistic overlap between the languages [cf. 27,28].
registration_responses.q5: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.
q6: No blinding is involved in this study.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to analysis of the data
registration_responses.q11:
Data are part of a larger, longitudinal study investigating literacy development in multilingual populations. Data for the present study are cross-sectional and have been collected as the first time-point in the larger project.
Any analyses already performed were done for validation purposes during development of our indices only. No analysis pertaining to the present research questions and hypotheses were done.
Neuroimaging data have been preprocessed, following established protocols for fMRI experi-ments (motion correction, spatial smoothing, registration to a common template, see Section ‘Measured variables Neuroimaging data’ for further details), followed by time-series statistical analyses on individual level. Similar to our behavioral measures, no investigation concerning the comparisons of interest for the current study has been performed.
registration_responses.q13:
A total of 184 children participated in at least one of our behavioral assessments and were invited for the neuroimaging experiment; the available full behavioral dataset (including all dependent and independent variables) comprises of 160 data points. 
157 children took part in the neuroimaging data collection. Two experimental tasks will be analyzed: English auditory word match task and English auditory semantic word match task (see ‘Measured variables’ Section for more details). Due to movement during the fMRI scans, failure to complete all experimental runs or hardware changes, respectively 101 and 98 datasets are available for higher-level analyses in the current study.
registration_responses.q14: A priori power analyses for sample size calculation have been conducted with a different, longitudinal design in mind. With the available sample size, for frequentist multiple regression analyses, the available sample size gives us the sensitivity for detecting a medium effect size (ƒ2 = 0.18) at alpha = .05 (Bonferroni corrected) and with .95 power [43].
registration_responses.q20: All data will be mean centered for the analyses.
registration_responses.q21:
Three types of inference criteria will be employed: frequentist, Bayesian and visual inspection of the data. For frequentist approaches, will use the standard p < .05 criterion for determining if the models suggest that the results are significantly different from those expected if the null hypothesis were correct. Bayes factors will be used and interpreted following [72–77] and will inform our models selection. We will compare models with BIC [78] and the difference between two BICs will be converted into a Bayes factor using the equation below, following [74]: (see attached)

Visual inspection of the relationship observed in the data will be employed for the rolling window regression analysis (Hypothesis I) and to evaluate the moderation effects (Hypothesis III). All voxel-wise visualizations of the BOLD data will be subject to visual interpretation (in conjunction with the use of anatomical atlases available via the visualization software).
registration_responses.q22: Data have been excluded at level of preprocessing due to: missing data, movement during fMRI scans (> 5mm), failure to complete all experimental runs, and hardware changes. In addition, we will not analyze data with lower than chance accuracy on the tasks, or data from participants who have not been exposed to English from birth.
registration_responses.q23: Only participants who provided complete datasets will be included in the analyses.
